title: José Martínez (outfielder/first baseman)
text:
José Alberto Martínez (born July 25, 1988) is a Venezuelan <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="first%20baseman">first baseman</a> and <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> who is a free agent. He previously played in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB) for the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a>, <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Rays">Tampa Bay Rays</a>, and <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a>. He made his major league debut with the Cardinals on September 6, 2016, after 887 games in ten <a href="Minor%20League%20Baseball">minor league</a> seasons.
As a member of the <a href="Triple-A%20%28baseball%29">Triple-A</a> <a href="Omaha%20Storm%20Chasers">Omaha Storm Chasers</a> in the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Royals">Kansas City Royals</a> organization in 2015, Martínez set a modern-day <a href="Pacific%20Coast%20League">Pacific Coast League</a> (PCL) record with a .384 <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a>. He also previously played in the <a href="Chicago%20White%20Sox">Chicago White Sox</a> and <a href="Atlanta%20Braves">Atlanta Braves</a> organizations as well as in the <a href="Frontier%20League">Frontier League</a>.
Playing career.
Chicago White Sox.
Martínez signed with the <a href="Chicago%20White%20Sox">Chicago White Sox</a> as an amateur free agent in February 2006. From 2006 to 2012, Martínez played in the White Sox organization, reaching as high as the Double-A <a href="Birmingham%20Barons">Birmingham Barons</a> before becoming a minor league free agent on November 2, 2012.
Atlanta Braves.
On March 23, 2013, Martínez signed a minor league contract with the <a href="Atlanta%20Braves">Atlanta Braves</a>. He spent the year with the <a href="Mississippi%20Braves">Mississippi Braves</a> and was a SOU South Division All-Star. On November 4, 2013, Martínez elected free agency. 
Rockford Aviators.
Martínez signed with the <a href="Rockford%20Aviators">Rockford Aviators</a> of the <a href="Frontier%20League">Frontier League</a>, an <a href="Independent%20baseball%20league">independent league</a>, for the 2014 season. In his time with the Aviators, Martínez slashed .337/.375/.444 in a little over 100 at-bats.
Atlanta Braves (second stint).
On June 20, 2014, he re-signed with the Braves and was assigned to the High-A <a href="Lynchburg%20Hillcats">Lynchburg Hillcats</a>, where he hit .319/.375/.444.
Kansas City Royals.
On January 28, 2015, Martínez signed with the <a href="2015%20Kansas%20City%20Royals%20season">Kansas City Royals</a>. While playing for the <a href="Omaha%20Storm%20Chasers">Omaha Storm Chasers</a> that year, his .384 <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a> broke a modern-day <a href="Pacific%20Coast%20League">Pacific Coast League</a> (PCL) record. He also led the PCL in <a href="on-base%20percentage">on-base percentage</a> (OBP, .461) and was an <a href="Triple-A%20All-Star%20Game">All-Star</a>. He batted .382 overall in 2015–which included rehab time in the <a href="Arizona%20League">Arizona League</a>–good for the fifth-highest mark since the modern era of the minor leagues began in 1963. Martinez was ultimately seven hits short of batting .400 for the season. 
The Royals added Martínez to the 40-man roster on November 6, <a href="2016%20Kansas%20City%20Royals%20season">2015</a>, and <a href="designated%20for%20assignment">designated him for assignment</a> on May 18, 2016, in favor of <a href="Whit%20Merrifield">Whit Merrifield</a>. One week later, they traded him to the <a href="2016%20St.%20Louis%20Cardinals%20season">St. Louis Cardinals</a> for cash.
St. Louis Cardinals.
After 887 games with 11 minor league teams, Martínez made his major league debut on September 6, 2016, against the <a href="2016%20Pittsburgh%20Pirates%20season">Pittsburgh Pirates</a>. He ground out as a pinch-hitter in the seventh inning in his first <a href="at%20bat">at bat</a>. His first major league <a href="Hit%20%28baseball%29">hit</a> and <a href="run%20batted%20in">run batted in</a> (RBI) occurred two days later, scoring <a href="Greg%20Garcia%20%28baseball%29">Greg Garcia</a> on an <a href="Infield%20hit">infield single</a> in a 12−5 loss to the <a href="2016%20Milwaukee%20Brewers%20season">Milwaukee Brewers</a>. For the season, he had 7 hits in 16 at bats.
The Cardinals announced that Martínez made their <a href="2017%20St.%20Louis%20Cardinals%20season">2017</a> <a href="Opening%20Day">Opening Day</a> roster, his first in the major leagues, after leading the club with 19 hits and 15 RBI in <a href="spring%20training">spring training</a>. He hit his first major league home run against the <a href="2017%20Toronto%20Blue%20Jays%20season">Toronto Blue Jays</a> on April 25. On August 6, 2017, Martínez hit his first major league career <a href="Grand%20slam%20%28baseball%29">grand slam</a> off <a href="Homer%20Bailey">Homer Bailey</a> of the <a href="2017%20Cincinnati%20Reds%20season">Cincinnati Reds</a>, cementing a nine run frame for the Cardinals in a 13–4 win. For the season, he batted .309/.379/.518.
Martínez began 2018 as St. Louis' starting first baseman. On June 8, 2018, he hit two home runs off of <a href="Matt%20Harvey">Matt Harvey</a> of the <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a> at <a href="Great%20American%20Ball%20Park">Great American Ball Park</a>, helping St. Louis defeat the Reds 7-6 in ten innings. He finished his 2018 campaign slashing .305/.364/.457 with 17 home runs and 83 RBIs in 152 games, and led the majors in percentage of balls hit to the <a href="opposite%20field">opposite field</a> (34.7%), as well as in percentage of soft-hit batted balls (34.7%).
In February 2019, Martínez signed a two-year, $3.25 million contract with St. Louis. For the 2019 regular season, he batted .269/.340/.751 with ten home runs and 42 RBIs over 128 games.
Tampa Bay Rays.
On January 9, 2020, Martínez was traded to the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Rays">Tampa Bay Rays</a> along with <a href="Randy%20Arozarena">Randy Arozarena</a> and the Cardinals’ Competitive Balance Round A draft pick in exchange for <a href="Matthew%20Liberatore">Matthew Liberatore</a>, Edgardo Rodriguez, and the Rays’ pick in Competitive Balance Round B.
Chicago Cubs.
On August 30, 2020, Martinez was traded to the <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a> in exchange for Pedro Martinez and cash considerations. On December 2, Martinez was non-tendered by the Cubs.
New York Mets.
On January 14, 2021, Martínez signed a one-year, split contract with the <a href="New%20York%20Mets">New York Mets</a>, which includes a $1 million option if he makes the team after spring training. On March 7, 2021, Martínez suffered a torn meniscus in his left knee after colliding with an umpire trying to field a ground ball, forcing him to be out for about four months. On April 1, Martínez was placed on the 60-day injured list. He played on a rehab assignment for the <a href="Syracuse%20Mets">Syracuse Mets</a>, but injured his elbow. Martínez elected free agency on October 29.
Personal life.
Martínez is a son of former <a href="infielder">infielder</a> <a href="Carlos%20Mart%C3%ADnez%20%28infielder%29">Carlos Martínez</a>, who played seven seasons in MLB for the <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a>, White Sox and <a href="1995%20California%20Angels%20season">California Angels</a>. He lives in <a href="Edwardsville%2C%20Illinois">Edwardsville, Illinois</a> during the season.
Martínez has two children; one son, and one daughter.
